unnormalised: ## The Aadhaar Adventure: One Card, Many Headaches (and Hopefully, Solutions!)
normalised: ## The Aadhaar Adventure: One Card, Many Headaches (and Hopefully, Solutions!)

unnormalised: So, there I was, standing in line at the bank. Typical Monday morning, right? Except, I needed to update my KYC. "Aadhaar card, please," the teller said, with that practiced, slightly-impatient smile they all seem to have. I rummaged through my wallet, the familiar panic rising. Where was it? I distinctly remember putting it in the designated "important documents" section. This is when the adventure began, or rather, the headache.
normalised: So, there I was, standing in line at the bank. Typical Monday morning, right? Except, I needed to update my K-Y-C. "Aadhaar card, please," the teller said, with that practiced, slightly-impatient smile they all seem to have. I rummaged through my wallet, the familiar panic rising. Where was it? I distinctly remember putting it in the designated "important documents" section. This is when the adventure began, or rather, the headache.

unnormalised: My Aadhaar, no. 2345-6789-0123 (not really mine, don’t worry!), is more than just a piece of plastic with my face on it. It's linked to everything, it seems! My bank account, my mobile number, even my cooking gas subsidy. Losing it felt like losing a vital organ, a digital kidney or something.

unnormalised: First stop, home. I tore the place apart. Under the sofa, in the bookshelf, even in the cookie jar (don't judge!). Nothing. My wife, Priya, bless her heart, just shook her head and muttered something about my organizational skills. She did, however, remind me that I might have scanned a copy.

unnormalised: Aha! Progress! I found a digital copy saved on my computer. Relief washed over me, until I remembered the bank teller's stern look the last time I tried to use a printout. "Original document required, sir," she’d said. I remembered her mentioning UIDAI, the Unique Identification Authority of India. My next stop was their website, a labyrinth of FAQs and downloadable forms.

My next stop was their website, a labyrinth of F-A-Q-s and downloadable forms.

unnormalised: Turns out, I could apply for a reprint online! But of course, there was a catch. I needed my registered mobile number to receive the OTP for verification. And guess what? The number registered was one I'd stopped using ages ago! Cue another wave of panic. This was turning into a real saga.
normalised: Turns out, I could apply for a reprint online! But of course, there was a catch. I needed my registered mobile number to receive the O-T-P for verification. And guess what? The number registered was one I'd stopped using ages ago! Cue another wave of panic. This was turning into a real saga.

unnormalised: After a lot of frantic Googling and calling customer care (wait time: 20 mins!), I learned that I could update my mobile number by visiting an Aadhaar Seva Kendra. Nearest one? 15 km away! Sigh. Off I went, battling Bangalore traffic (it was 4:00 PM, peak hour, naturally).

Nearest one? fifteen kilometer away! Sigh. Off I went, battling Bangalore traffic (it was four P-M, peak hour, naturally).

unnormalised: Finally, after what felt like an eternity, I managed to update my mobile number. Reprints take approximately 5 working days, and cost Rs. 50. So, long story short, I’m still waiting for my reprinted Aadhaar card. The moral of the story? Keep your Aadhaar safe, folks. And definitely keep your registered mobile number updated!
